user_texts: ['Very beautiful view once you reach the summit ! Get up there early and earn the sunrise!', 'great views at top.', 'Great challenging hike to the top of the summit. Great views and view of Lake Hodges. Will hike again.', 'This is a really nice hike up to the Bernardo Summit. The terrain varies from flat, to rocky and some decent inclines. It is a well worn trail that are shared with mountain bikers, hikers and trail runners. I would say it is a good trail for most, there were some seniors and children on the trail, so use your best judgment. There are several different trails that can be taken, I was on the one marked “Bernardo Mountain Summit” which takes you to rattlesnake view point. If you are going in the summer or hot in general, start early mornings to avoid heat issues, not a lot of shaded areas and in the summer Escondido gets well over 90 degs, so hotter on the mountain. Overall a great work out, great views and round trip was about 4.5 miles', 'First/last mile against major highway.  once away from it the hike got much better.  little shade but nice views.', 'Great!Took my 4 month old and it was varied enough in terrain and trail alone to keep him entertained!Difficulty varied with multiple hills despite climbs by a hill!!I will do it again!', 'Great hike! Even if you are out of shape, I believe  you can still conquer it lol. My wife and my 7 year old was able to finish it under 3hrs. Beautiful view of Lake Hodge, Escondido, and RB!', 'Nice semi-strenuous hike near Escondido. Great views near and at the summit.', 'Easy to moderate hike and the view at the summit is worth the hike. Nice to see that in the midst of suburbs, nature is still abundant and accessible. Along the trail, you can enjoy the various wildflowers in bloom.', 'I love this hike- flat enjoyable path around lake to gradual incline to pretty steep hike as you get to the top- Im older so I find this challenging enough for exercise- always see quail and roadrunner or two with nice view of lake- love it!', 'Not crowded during midday. Some rocky sections but mostly towards the top. Views of other mountains and rooftops of houses.', 'Great hike. Rated appropriately in this app. Good hike even for senior hikers. 360 Panoramic view at the top. Not to crowded in Feb. and breeze was nice in places during the hike.', 'Loved it!  It was a great afternoon. The dog loved it, too. The trail is narrow in some areas so single file hiking. And if there’s a bike it’s tight. For those who consider this “easy”.... perhaps Mt Fuji would be more appropriate for you. ', 'Beautiful Views at the top!', 'Easy to moderate I would say. Not much to see until you get to the peak.', 'My 6 yr. old and I did this trail not to long ago and had a great time. Great views from the peak.', 'Too many snakes on trail. Yikes!!!', 'Great views from top, a few moderate inclines. Dog friendly on leash.', 'I would say this trail is easy to moderate. pretty flat for a majority of the hike.', 'Great little hike to the top. I’m in love with the view from the summit.', "We'll traveled and comfortable enough to hike alone. I climbed on Saturday, August 26th. About 10:30 am I left my trekking poles leaning against the wooden fence posts inside the parking lot, near the design sign of the park. Anyone find them? I just now realized they are missing. Thanks in advance.", 'I really enjoy running this trail from Rancho Bernardo Glassman Recreation Center, across the bridge and up the mountain. Exactly 7 miles round trip. Rocky and steep at times, but beautiful view at the top!', 'Fantastic!! Hiked it on 12aug17', 'A nice clean well maintained trail. Part paved, part sand/dirt, and part rock & gravel towards the top. Popular for mountain bikes until you reach the summit turn off. 360 view from the top of Lake Hodges and Escondido. The hum of the 15 traffic is constant.', "The hardest part was getting to the right trail. We hiked a wrong direction for a mile when we started..... Glad I had the AllTrails app on. Once incline starts, it gets fairly rocky and steep but we (me and 6 yr old son) made it and the view from the top was awesome! On a side note, this may not be a best hike for younger kids like my son. It really isn't so pretty on the way up you can't really see great views. We've tried Woodson and Cowles I'd say this one was unique.", 'Not very pretty while you are climbing, but the view at the top is really great. You can run this trail if you want to make it a little tougher. Mind the rocks because they are ankle killers.', 'The lower trial is soft and wide, great running conditions. Once the incline begins, it gets pretty rocky at several spots but still run-able. Excellent 360 view at summit. Well worth it.', 'great view of the lake, not too crowded today', '', '', "Well kept. Easy until you start approaching the top, then it's pretty steep. Low traffic once you start up the summit trail. A bit too urban is the only complaint, but an undeniably beautiful view.", 'Beautiful hike. Well maintained trail', 'A tough run with good elevation gain and views atop the summit.  Tricky single track in most of the trail about 2 miles in due to bikes, walkers and dogs.  Beautiful right now with all the water and flowers.  I like to start across the bridge near RB Community Park versus near Adobe house due to the congestion and pavement at trail head.', "Great trail, lots of rocks going up the hill. Weather was perfect high 70's to low 80's.", "Morning hike with family. Beautiful hike. My only complaint would be the road bikes that are very quiet coming up behind you. It's hard to move out of the way if your engaged in conversation and don't hear them coming.  There's no need to be rude about it either, we didn't hear you jack knife. Mountain bikes were louder and more courteous, perhaps the mountain bike riders are familiar with walking a trail as well as riding it, so they get the dilemma.", 'A good workout. real suburban.', 'It was a decent hike', 'Excellent hike with panoramic view at the very top you can see the ocean in the distance on a clear day with the lakes and mountains nearby. Must go to the top!', 'This was an easy-moderate trail to hike, with many other options along the way to extend your journey. Great views from the top of the ocean, mountains, and all of San Diego County!  Definitely going back!', "This trail had some good variety. It starts off deceivingly easy on mostly flat trails until the last third where it's a bit more rocky and steep. From this starting point you get a mixture of paved, dirt, and rocky paths. You cross a little stream which was cool and have a few pretty lake views along the way and at the top. Excited to check out some of the other trails in this area!", 'Beatiful views at sunset.', 'I have hiked Coast to Crest a few times before, as I have just started hiking a few months ago. I finally decided to try this trail and I was surprised at how long it was and how I would think I was at the top but I still had like 5 more inclined switch backs. As a overweight gal just starting to do moderate hikes, this one was interesting. But once I got to the top, it was worth it.', "I hiked this peak 20 years ago and decided to do it again. I'm so glad that I did! Great moderate hike. I even took my pup who did great, but got a little tired coming down the hill. So I took it easy on the way back down. Bring water and plan for a few hours. Great training hike!", 'Nice hike, good workout and views without traveling too dar to do it.', 'I did this hike today from the parking lot at the end of Sunset Drive and it was 8.2 miles. Great long hike, very easy, with only a few moderate spots. I really appreciated this app today because it helped me find my way on a few spots that were not marked well. Will definitely do again but would not take this hike again at sunset because the view on the way up was nice but dark and long on the way back. Also there were only a few other hikers on the summit portion so that was nice.', 'Nice training hike. Started off at about 0700 with a 30 pound pack. I was able to complete this hike in 2 hrs 27 min and had 7.76 as the mileage (did not include about a 30 minute break at the top). There were lots of options to make this hike shorter or longer and plenty of people on the trail. Mostly bikers and some trail runners. I noticed at the San Dieguito Park there were other trails that head off into other directions and offer different challenges. I will certainly come back any try these trails as well. All of them are a part of the Coast to Crest Trail.', 'Was a nice hike with some challenges and some easy spots. Nice change of pace when you are tired.', 'We started our hike at Piedras Pintadas and walked across the pedestrian bridge. It was a cloudy cool day fro a hike up the summit.', 'Hike was great.  Good mix between inclines and straightaways.   Was terrific!', 'Nice trail with few people even on a Sunday morning', "Great hike.  Not super strenuous.  I'd go so far as to call it moderate to easy.  Great views from the top, and not very many other people.", "Great mix of incline and straight always. Loved that it wasn't too crowded (went on a Saturday too)", "Super fun, my man and I do it all the time. We get on through residential and run it, so it's much shorter.", "It was a tough run because I thought it was a good idea to do it on a 'dry run.'Nice view on top, however it was kinda funky going around the water thingie.", 'It was an alright hike, not too memorable, except for the views at the summit.', 'Loved the view.   Thought it might be too easy at the beginning but half way through it was a good challenge.  Would recommend this anytime.  Take your dog with you.  Cooper loved it too.', 'Great workout, you get a good little view, nothing spectacular but nevertheless a great hike. Coming back down goes by much quicker than going up. Does not feel like over 7 miles at all though. Watch out for mountain bikers :)', 'This review pertains to the entire hike from San Dieguito River Park off Via Rancho Parkway to the top of Bernardo Mountain and back. Total distance was just under 8 miles, and bear in mind I did this in mid-December when the weather is cool even at midday.    For starters: the San Dieguito River Park Rangers are pretty awesome.  I got into a long conversation with Brian, a Ranger before I set out and he explained the entire breadth of the watershed especially the Coast to Crest Trail and how far along the SDRP had come in establishing the trail officially.  He was even able help me identify the un-named yet beflagged peninsula that juts out into the Lake Hodges Reservoir (It\'s Fletcher Point, or Flag point colloquially).  Anyway, hats off to the Rangers, and Brian especially.   The hike itself is typical San Diego: hilly, shrubby, boulder-y, you get my drift. Passing under the 15 was interesting but unspectacular.  I do reccomend veering off trail about a mile and a half in to peruse the work of Escondido\'s local graffiti artists.  An embankment with a grey boulder of immense size can be seen from the trail against the edge of a neighborhood.  The grey boulder has been utterly destroyed, no doubt by the community developer many years ago. The pit is now filled with a rusty bicycle and shards of hundreds of beer bottles, all of which is surrounded by fairly extravagant graffiti.  They\'ve been using alot more than just spraypaint here.  Take some time and take a look.   If that kind of thing bothers you, ask yourself who\'s done more damage; the developer or the beer guzzling artisits?    Moving up the trail a small bridge erected by "Team Trailbuilders" will take you over an absolutely lovely little creek to the Bernardo Summitt Trailhead.  As you follow the north side of the mountain keep an eye out below, as that creek\'s source is in full view most of the way.  It\'s an exceptionally pretty valley with tall Palm and Eucalyptus trees, and I believe it houses multiple murders of crows, at least it seemed to on my way down.    Bernardo Mountain will not be necessarily easy.  I reccomend bringing trekking poles to make sure you don\'t slip on the way back down, but most hikers won\'t need them.  The peak itself has great views of Lake Hodges all the way out to the ocean, and during the summer would be an incredible spot to watch the sunset.  I\'m giving it 5 stars because it includes so much and because of the SDRP Rangers.  Don\'t miss this hike. It\'s worth it. Happy Hiking', 'nice diverse terrain and nice gain, but too narrow for mixed trail.', 'Nice view, not crowded. Road runners, quails, rattlers, and even deer sometimes by the freeway.', 'Not great views (though the lake is nice) and not great conditions, but a good place to get out and cover some miles for training.  Consider adding some distance by parking at Rancho Bernardo community park south of the lake and hiking across the foot/bike bridge.', "Strange trail.  Park next to highway, walk on pavement for about a mile.   Then dirt road for another mile and then get to trailhead.  once on trailhead the hike is nice, not much shade at all, just FYI.   The last mile or so to summit is steep and rocky but I kind of like that.   Only 3 stars because of how odd it is.   Lots of mountain bikers today that don't obey the speed limits set and think they have the right of way, they don't.   It was over 8 miles RT from the parking area so the 7.2 must be somewhere starting near the suspension bridge.   Overall, the views from the top are very nice and don't forget to sign the sheet in the ammo box at the top.   I always like that touch.", "This place is  great for mountain biking. If you ride to the dam it's amazing. Don't ride after dark. You will more than liking get ticketed.  Been on thsee trails plenty of times. Yes bring plenty of water, binos or/camera. Moderate decent for family trips and beginners.", "First and foremost, bring bug spray and a large stick.  There are several slithery and buzzy critters that roam about.  With that being said, this trail is no doubt moderate but nonetheless still challenging.  I say this because it gets steep for a good portion of the hike and is very jagged, so bring thick soled shoes.  I wore Vibrams.  It also doesn't help that I wore a 35 pound rucksack.  Regardless, the view at the top is rewarding, but I definitely wouldn't go at noon.  It's a good hike but be mindful that the trail can be very brushy for a long period, lots of vegetation so watch for snakes and such.  A really nice thing about this trail is not many people are on it, so if you want some solitude, this is your best bet.  The walk from the parking lot to the trailhead is long and boring, so be prepared for that.  I liked this hike!", 'Recommend going on a Sunday morning so you can enjoy the farmers market when your done.', "Way less crowded than Woodson or Iron. Have to walk on pavement and dirt roads a couple miles, pretty flat terrain, until you finally get to the trailhead that leads to the summit. From there it has some steep sections, and although I didn't bring my trekking pole, it wasn't a problem.", "Odd beginning but once you hit the actual trail I like it a lot. Great view from the top if you catch sunset, just head back when there's enough light.", 'Went with my hiking group again today,  nice work out. this is our 6th visit I think, great cool weather and not too crowded at 8 :00 am.  Views are always  great,  and now crowds today.', "I'm not sure how, but I went the wrong way twice. I had the hardest time actually finding the trailhead to the summit. The sign faces west, so if you're coming from the east it's easy to miss. There are a lot of bikers too, so be prepared to share the road. If you just want to get out and move and be outside it a decent hike; not very challenging thou.", 'Nice hike.  Once off the main trail and wrapping around the mountain you can find some solitude.', 'My new favorite run! Just the right difficulty - challenging but runable all the way. I went up Sunday morning with my  10 and 12 year old grandkids,and everyone was able to run to the top without walking.\nThey loved the log book. It was there first time logging a summit. If you are a trail runner, it is harder than Ramona dam,but easier than Woodson. Great views and nice single track.', 'Great hike with a variety of views and terrain.  Parts of the trail are fairly steep and/or have loose rocks.  Feels like a real hike without having to drive too far (for us anyway!).  Recommend hitting the trail early to avoid the midday heat.', "Fantastic views at the top.  Gets very hot in the summer so hike early.   Lots of rocks so I'd recommend hiking boots.", "Pretty good little hike. It can get pretty crowded depending on the day. Usually there are a lot of mountain bikers as well. There is some shade but I wouldn't depend on it. At the top of the peak is a Folgers can with little notes that people put in there and a pretty good view of Lake Hodges.", "One of my favorite local San Diego hikes.  Nice elevation gain so you can get a good workout if you want or just take it slow.  Beautiful views from the summit.  Trail is rocky in sections so watch your footing if you're moving fast down hill.  Little crowded the first mile then once the trail narrows you lose most mountain bikers.  During the week you can have the trail to yourself.", "My husband and I did this hike this past Sunday morning.  Finding the trailhead was a little confusing for us at first because it looked like we ended up at a golf course. After a few minutes of driving around we finally found the small parking lot right next to the trail.  The beginning of the hike is paved and goes directly under the freeway before getting to the actual Bernardo Mountain summit trail.  There were lots of people out, especially mountain bikers.  Before the trail gets very steep or technical for the bikers, expect some traffic from other people of all activity levels.  Since the trail is in such a densely populated area you will never really feel like you are out on a hike away from everything. I still enjoyed the hike because it was a new place for us to explore, but I cant say that I would go back and do it again.  if you plan on biking to the summit (we only saw one rider go all the way to the top) be ready for some technical spots. I am not a mountain biking enthusiast, but it looks pretty tricky in parts especially where there are washouts.On another note, I understand that parts of the trail are wide, but I always prefer when riders ring a bell or announced that they are coming up behind us.  Most riders on this trail don't do that, but I always appreciated the few that did.", "Unexpectedly great hike!  Didn't know if I was going the right way until about a mile in when there was a sign for Bernardo Mtn on a trail that veered off to the right.  Went a couple hours before sundown and I couldn't have planned it better if I tried!  Amazing views from the top & a pretty good work out too.", "I really enjoyed this hike. I went on a Saturday morning, the temperature was cool which made it easier to hike. The path is clear, but there is over-grown brush, so be careful of poison oak and you'll see the warning sign right as you pass the creek. There is incline with flat surfaces off and on throughout the trail, which makes it easy to want to jog the flat part of the trail and walk the incline parts. Bring water and I wouldn't recommend this hike in the Summer as there is hardly any shade. When you get to the top, you will see some of the most beautiful views of Escondido. Lake Hodges, surrounding mountains, the ocean, and most of the city. Enjoy!!!", "it was a good hike. the trees were a good break from the heat. you get a view of the freeway and the houses.  they have farmer's market on sundays. i like how it wasn't crowded at all and it was a good length with a steady elevation.", 'Bernardo Mountain is a good mellow trail for anyone who wants to do some distance but not have a huge incline. The trail takes a mellow path from the trailhead on the other side of the freeway around the lake and around the mountain. The trail for the most part is pretty well maintained and would easily work for mountain bikers as well as hikers.', "The only bad part of this trail is starting and ending right next to the freeway.  Once you get past the freeway and start going up the mountain it is great.  The climb to the top of Bernardo Peak is a great workout and the views of the lake are awesome.  There is a bathroom located near the foot bridge going across the lake but you must bring plenty of water.  Most people bypass the trail leading to the peak so it won't be crowded like Iron Mountain or Mt. Woodson.  Even on the weekends you might only see a couple other people going up the mountain.", 'She hated it. I enjoyed it. Lol. Trail has a lot of routes. Making it all the way to the top is the bigGest Reward. Just lay out on the rocks and prEpare your body for the wAlk back. Very scenic if your inTo big houses with pools. And for Those who only went half way... Yes, theRe is a trail to the top.', "We actually went all the way up the mountain. I don't know why that trail isn't shown when I favorite it. I loved this trail though! Great for dogs, and it wasn't hard at all :) Get there early though, the trail gets a little crowded.", 'Love this trail! Kicked my ass but it felt so great making it to the top! ', "Dude, it's real hard but doable! ", 'Good for dogs. Best to do in cooler temps.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Parker Mesa Overlook Trail - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['kid friendly', 'birding', 'hiking', 'mountain biking', 'nature trips', 'trail running', 'walking', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife', 'no dogs']
hike_description: Parker Mesa Overlook Trail is a 6.5 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Topanga, California that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round.

user_texts: ['The parking is crowded, and so is the ascent/approach trail for this and Los Liones Canyon. While the ascent trail is a promising single track, about the time you complete the ascent and the 405-size crowds die out, the trail becomes a flattish fire road. From then on, the trail is devoid of anything interesting besides the views over the Pacific.a good workout, but will not repeat.', 'One of my favorite hikes either from the ocean side via sunset blvd or the valley side via Topanga State Park.... end views are awesome try going after rain for clearer sky’s and less people', 'Amazing views throughout and wide, well kept trails.', 'We started early at 6:45 AM and noticed a lot of cars park already. Coming from Los Leones Canyon entrance trail, it is 1.5 miles of narrow and relaxing hike with trail covered with trees. Then  you will be exposed to open overlooking views of ocean and city and there is a bench for resting. Then the rest of your 2 mile trail to the Parker Mesa overlook will be wide and exposed  with few inclines that will give you your cardio workout. The overlook is amazing and breathtaking on a clear day.', 'Very nice and clean trail. It was an easy trail, very little inclines. About 6.8 miles back and fourth trail. Connects to los Leones trail and got to see that beautiful ocean view. Hiked Labor Day 2018 at 12 pm, very little traffic. Perfect running trail for the way down.', 'Beautiful view', 'This was one of the more scenic hikes I’ve done in LA. The views (on a clear day) are amazing and once you hit the peak you get a nice [reward] panoramic view of the shoreline and cityscape. I clocked in 7 miles from start to finish on this one.  I would rate this as an easy to moderate hike. It’s an incline for most of the way up (not TOO steep but does give you a workout) but there are many parts of level ground. What makes it a bit more strenuous is the distance. The trail is exposed so bring hats, wear sunscreen and bring water. I went around 2pm and ran into hikers/bikers maybe every quarter mile or so, not too busy. Saw people coming up to the overlook point from different trails so assuming many other trails lead to this peak.', '', 'Great trail, beautiful views! Would put this towards more moderate but well worth it. We got there early, 8.30am Saturday morning and were only a couple of other people around. Got a lot busier on the way back around 11am.', 'One of my favorite hikes in L.A. if you want to make this hike more challenging, there is an alternate route that will turn this into a 5 mile loop. From the main entrance on los liones, go left and down to cross the concrete. Follow the trail and about 50 meters in you will see another trail on your left that goes up the steep hillside. From there it is 1.4 miles to parker mesa overlook but be warned it is quite steep.  You will gain 1300 feet in 1.4 miles, expect to cover this distance in 45 minutes to an hour depending on how many breaks you take. Shoes with good traction are recommended. I take this way up and the regular easy way down to make it a loop, going back this way is not recommended as it is quite steep.', "A moderate hike, mostly uphill. Try to start in the afternoon after the fog is lifted otherwise you won't get much of a view.", 'Beautiful views, I would do this trail again.', 'Amazing hike, great views, and fun.', 'One of my favorite LA hikes; nice views and a good workout.', 'The views are fantastic!! Good calorie burner too', 'This is a moderately difficult hike. Steep up hill and down.   Beautiful views are your reward.', 'Beautiful scenery', 'Easy trail open spaces and you are not too exposed.', "It isn't really easy...more like moderate in my opinion...1,300 ft of elevation gain after all.", "My favorite trail in LA! It's a long one but the view at the end is worth all your hard work", '', 'This is my go to trail when I just need to get out of the house.', "This is one of my favorites. Last time I hiked it was 3/19 and when I got to the top the entire ocean view was covered in clouds so it looked like I was on top of the clouds! I started late and got back to the parking lot later than I wanted to. The whole trail is about 6 miles and pretty easy but there's some incline so allow yourself a few hours. Parking is available on the street before you enter the park so you don't have to pay.", 'i was scrolling through the list, looking for a new trail, when I saw that this one was labeled easy.  Having done it several times, I didnt recall it being that easy so I did it again.  It is easy if you hike a lot but given that it is 6 miles RT, about half of which is without shade, and that there are significant ascents and descents, I would rate it as moderate.  It is certainly easier than coming up the other side to Parker Mesa but not a walk in the park.  :-)', 'Great views', "This is one of my favorite trails in LA. Part of it is on fire roads so it's not like being in the backwoods but it's a good incline and one of my favorite views of LA.", 'I love this trail!!! The views are amazing!', 'Love this hike. There are beautiful ocean views on a clear day.', "First time to do hiking here but it's really worth it.", 'super easy and fun, took my mom, great scene of LA', 'Amazing view and definitely a leg workout different trails you could take, will be going back for sure', 'Completely worth it. The view was beautiful!', "This trail has nice views and it's a good leg workout. It took me 2hrs 1/2 to finish following the trail track, overall it has an awesome and peaceful view towards the ocean. ", 'The view was beautiful, one of my favorite hiking spots.', 'Easy trail. Parking $10. Great view. Hardly no shade.', 'Biked this trail on the hottest day of the year. Glad I started early! would not consider this easy as a biking trail - my computer calculated total elevation climbed of 1401 ft. But totally worth it as the views were amazing from the entire trail.', 'Going beyond Los Liones Trail to the Parker Mesa Overlook trail was a good decision, tiring, but good. Great ocean view once high enough. Lots of people to interact with, or not; but they were courteous. Mountain Bikers + a few kids spotted. Definitely bring water if going to tackle Parker Mesa Overlook Trail. It can kick butt if not prepared', "This is a really great hike. It isn't too hard. Has some beautiful scenery, clear trail markings, and a great destination", 'This was just ok.  Started at Los Liones.  Unfortunately, really no shade so that made the climb arduous.  Clouds rolled in and it made the rest of the hike super easy.  Nothing remarkable to see except when you reach the overlook.  On way back, near to bottom was busy with super slow walkers.  Did this hike in record time and felt it was boring.', "Don't do this hike in the summer... 20% shade... Started from Topanga State Park... Bring lots of water... Very dog friendly if the State Park allows it... But the view from the top is breath-taking!!! If doing this in summer START EARLY!! Before 7am!!", 'Flew all the way down from Seattle for this hike!  Actually was in town for business in Chatsworth and this looked perfect!  Great view and perfect distance!  Not easy by any means, but not hard. Bring Water!', "I was shocked to see this trail rated easy.  And then I saw that most enter the trail off of Topanga Cyn.  We entered it from Los Liones Canyon (off of Sunset Blvd.).  3.5 miles in and 3.5 miles out.  But the kicker is that it's 3.5 miles straight up.  Started at 10:30am (bad move....maximum heat time) and only made it 2.5 miles in (????).  I usually enjoy 8+ mile hikes.  Will definitely be back and climb my 3.5 miles straight up to earn the awesome view everyone is talking about (even though the views along the way were not too shabby).", 'great views, good one if you like populated trails.', "The hike is on a fire road, so if you're not a fan of fire road hiking, I'd recommend using a different trail to get to the overlook. Make sure to start your hike early because there's very little shade--we started at 11 and finished at 2--the worst possible time for this particular trail. The view at the overlook is very nice. Make sure to pack a lunch and allott yourself enough time to sit and enjoy the breeze, especially if you've hiked out on a hot day! The trail is very up and down, so it won't cut you much slack in either direction, but the overlook is worth it.", "The trail head is inside Topanga Canyon Park - find parking outside on Waveview Drive and walk into the park and save yourself ten bucks. The trail head is easy enough to find - the trails pretty wide and pretty friendly for runners and bikers. Arrive early because there isn't too much shade unfortunately on the trail itself, and it started to get pretty sunny and hot around 10 am on my run. The run toward Parker Mesa Overlook (3 miles each way, out and back) changes incline quite frequently, making it a challenging, but not too gruesome run.", "Great, hike. The weather was a pleasant 75 degrees with a slight Marine Layer coming in from the sea. Plenty of uphills and some down and the scenery when you reach the Overlook can take your breath away. Great day to spend with God and Fellowship with some Disciples. After the hike we went to Denny's and broke bread together. Great start to a beautiful weekend. I'll add that if you continue on Entrada Road where a tri-section of Wave View Drive, Entrada Rd, and Colina Drive. You can park in this area for free but be early.", 'My son and I hiked the Parker Mesa Overlook last Sunday. Luckily we left our dog at home as there are no dogs allowed on this trail. More of a long walk than hike, we did not see a lot of wildlife, but there are several overlooks that are somewhat inspiring, the first one of Topanga Canyon Blvd. below. However, if you go to the end of the trail the trek is well worth it... Incredible views of the Pacific Coastline all the way up to Santa Monica and you can also see Downtown L.A. from the same vista point. There are a lot of people on this trail. All in all a good time to chat, but not that interesting until the end. We made it at a moderate pace in 2 - 1/2 hours.  There is a trail that veers off towards the end that goes down to the beach. ', 'short nice leisure pays off Santa Monica coastal view at the top', "Phenomenal views! If you are rusty mountain biking then I recommend turning back to the parking lot after viewing the overlook. If you continue to the gate you get good solid downhill ride, weaving through hikers the whole way, but that means you have a consistent 1.5 mile uphill back to the overlook.  If I were to do it again I'd have a car waiting at the gate to take us back to the first car parked at the parking lot.", '7am start time.  Fun ride from Entrada to Parker Mesa.  2hrs total just chillin.  Lots of up hills and lots of downhills there and on the way back.', 'The views from various points on the fire road are fantastic but the over hiking experience is average. Outside of the view points, the single track approach trail from Los Liones is the nicest part of the hike. ', 'This was my second time hiking in Topanga State Park. Previously, I did the Eagle Rock trail and decided I wanted to get closer to the ocean this time. I started a little after 8am on a day that was supposed to peak at 90 degrees around noon. Needless to say, I was on a race to finish the entire trail before my skin melted off. It was really beautiful in the early morning because there was plenty of shade on the trails. However, on the way back it was quite brutal because rising run eliminating any shade. I had a hat which helped, but there\'s nothing you can do to escape the hot sun. It\'s definitely a motivator though.  \n\nWhen I finally reached the overlook, it was definitely beautiful but the seating capacity up there is just limited to two benches. This means that you don\'t have too much time to "soak in the view" and eating a snack might have to be done on a rock (like I did). I\'d recommend arriving earlier to hopefully avoid the crowds. At the end of the trail, I was glad to have conquered this trail. There were plenty of "rest moments" when the road was somewhat flat, but the occasional incline did kick my butt momentarily. I would recommend this to someone who wants to see a variety of ocean views throughout L.A.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Independence Trail West - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['dogs on leash', 'wheelchair friendly', 'kid friendly', 'stroller friendly', 'hiking', 'nature trips', 'walking', 'forest', 'river', 'views', 'waterfall', 'wildlife', 'bugs']
hike_description: Independence Trail West is a 4.9 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Nevada City, California that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and nature trips and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.

user_texts: ['Loved this one! We looped with the Jones Bar trail and it was a blast. Not very kid friendly over on the Jones bar  part because of steep terrain but still a good trail to hike.', 'Awesome family hike and very flat. Little chilly as most of the trail is shaded.', 'Forested, shady, level and incredible views. We took this hike this year around Christmas. The trees were damp with dew, and the sun was peeking through the fog, highlighting the South Yuba River Canyon. The forest is a mixture of Ponderosa, Digger, and other conifers, along with California Oak, Madrone and Manzanita. The best part of this trail is the bridges. The wooden walkways provide good photo spots and break up the trail length. Don’t be fooled by the mountainous topography. This trail is almost 100% level. Flat. In fact, we heard it was one of the first wheelchair accessible dirt trails constructed in the USA back in the 70s. It follows an irrigation ditch built by the Chinese in the 1800s. Now used as a hiking path. At times, we switched from the top to the bottom of the ditch. Consider the unique canyon boardwalk as the destination. Making it about an hour round-trip walk. Great for groups, or anyone looking for a level start. Bring high-soled shoes and trekking poles if you plan to hike in the winter, as the ditch can be muddy in some spots. - Mike and Angel Cutler, EarthTrek Gear', 'nice relaxing trail. I love going in the fall with the amazing color changes of the trees and salamanders every where.', 'I really enjoyed this hike! Ground was level and beautiful views and ran into some salamanders on the trail. Will definitely do it again!', "The trail itself is beautiful, and though I would not describe the views as spectacular, the jaunt itself is pleasant and relaxing. I took the trail from the (very low) underpass to the right of the trailhead sign all the way to it's finish at the fire road (there is an end of trail marker there to let you know). A little anticlimactic since there was no sweeping view at the end. When I do it again, i will likely stop at the picnic tables located after the bridge. Great place to snack and recharge before heading back.", 'Great trail! lots of mosquitoes though. Easy walk, level and shaded.', 'this is a fantastic trail to take young kids who are just starting to get into nature walks without being in a stroller. it is long but easy for them to enjoy and explore. the trail has several little creekbeds that are filled with salamanders. the walk bridgws and paths are also nice for individuals who have difficulty walking. bridges have benches and great views.', 'This trail is more a walking trail rather than a hiking trail. It’s very flat, mostly shaded, and provides a pretty nice view of the South Yuba river from above. It’s not a crowded trail since more people opt to spend time down by the river. The wooden bridges were a nice touch as well. From what I saw, it’s an in-out trail. The only drawback was having to avoid dog poop which was not moved from the trail.', 'It was a very relaxing trail to hike.  sad that part of it was damaged.', 'great for kids path is well maintained. a lot of people there so made it tricky for the narrow path', "The scenery on this trail is ever changing! Which made it interesting and fun:) It wasn't challenging in any way, very chill. Adorable, really. Good for everyone! Adults and kids. Wheelchairs not so much).", 'Was a great little trail. We had it all to ourselves.This would be a great walk for young children as well.We had an illusion that we were walking slightly down hill both ways ', 'the west trail is actually a loop of you take Jones bar and hike on the service road for a bit.  you will see where the west trail meets the road.  Take that back to the trail head.  Very nice and shady. The most  difficult part was the incline on  the service road. we then went to to the east trail.  This is an in and out trail.  Easy and flat.', 'We weren’t impressed. This is an in and out hike, which we knew to begin with. The hike halfway in was nice and very easy. It was also wide enough and very level for wheel chair accessibility. The wooden switchback was blocked off and deemed unsafe. We were able to navigate our way down but definitely not accessible in a wheelchair. It was the only point on the hike that any water was visible. The second half of the way in was level and very easy for an able person. The trail narrowed to the point that a wheel chair would not fit and tons of poison oak encroached the path. There was also two fallen trees blocking the path. The trail led to an end of trail marker...a huge disappointment for myself and my two teen boys. Apparently, in other reviews, we could have crossed what appeared to be a county maintained gravel road and scaled down some boulders to a swim pond. Didn’t realize that until later. We headed back and then drove down the hill to the bridge where we joined several others at the swimming hole. Lots of fun there. Next time, that’s where we will spend our time.', 'I am in a wheelchair (power) and this was amazing!!', 'Just wanted to clarify that following the dirt road to the right at the end of the trail leads to an absolutely beautiful spot but the loop back to the trail is a very tough vertical hike. You will find it on the other side of a wooden foot bridge.', 'so much beauty', 'Easy hike. Bring bug spray and watch for poison oak. It’s everywhere. We were a little confused about .5 miles into hike there was a trail that leads down. Jones Bar. We took it and realized a mile in that we were off the trail and had to turn around. So stay on the upper trail.', 'It\'s a very easy walk for strollers, well-behaved pets, and well-behaved 4-year-olds... but it\'s too easy to be a real "hike". I absolutely love that it\'s wheelchair accessible, and I saw a young lady out enjoying her outing with seemingly no problems. The view is amazing with beautiful flora!! The trail is clean and very well groomed with picnic tables and benches, but long pants are advised as Poison Oak grows in abundance near (and onto!) the pathway. Some areas can get hot where the breeze just doesn\'t reach.', 'Nice botany hike with my CNPS  colleagues. A lot of cool plants along the this little snippet of trail. I want to go back and hike some other areas, soon. Although I will be looking at plants, I can get more miles in with a smaller group.', 'Too easy for a hike but definitely a breath taking beautiful nature walk. Oh I forgot the mosquito repellent and was bit many times so don’t forget yours.', 'beautiful hike!  i knew better then to leave the house without bug spray(lesson learned). There is many mosquitoes and a ton of poison oak . it was so nice overall and i will be going again forsure. very easy hike', 'Amazing', 'beautiful easy trail with good accessibility.', 'Nice walk - nothing difficult. Not well marked at the end so tough to get down to the river. We ended up using a “trail” that required we navigate some big boulders (and lots of poison oak) but in the end it was all worth it', 'Great, easy hike with great views. We didn’t know you can make a loop and go down to the river. We went to the end of the trail and turned around and went back the way we came, so I would suggest that if you want to get to the river turn right at end end of the trail and follow the dirt road. All in all a really great hike.', 'The trail was awesome, easily accessible, and beautiful! The weather was perfect and the trail is full of many shady spots along the way to let the dogs take a rest and drink! The only reason the trail didn’t get 5 stars is due to the fact that there were massive amounts of poison oak growing alongside the trail, mosquitos (shady, moist, and warm, we should have known lol), and water access was not possible with the dogs...the descent was too steep. If you can handle the cons then the trail is MOST DEFINITELY worth the pros!', 'Great trail for your dogs, beautiful butterflies 曆. Trail is easy and many wooden bridges to cross.', 'Awesome!', 'Gorgeous hike. I love the bridges and there was a lot of newts or salamanders. Fairly easy terrain . Not sure that we went the right way as we followed the trail straight the whole way and ended up scaling down the mountain to the rocks and waterfall area below. It was pretty steep getting down and back up but the water below is worth it. We also wound up across from the nude beach which was entertaining .', 'Anyone been there recently? Wondering how water is currently. Speed of water safe for kids?', 'Walk across a cool bridge, then down hill to the river. Cool swimming ponds.', 'I wish the boardwalk down to Rush Creek was usable. The newts were fun to watch there. This is still an easy, fun trail for the whole range of ages as it is wide and level with the added interest of the flumes. Wildflowers abound.', 'Loved this, very easy trail and super pretty. The bridges and the falls are soooo perfect. I would go back, for sure!!!', 'Beautiful!  Easy access.', 'We love this trail it is such a friendly and nature loaded environment. I hope they decide to rebuild the bridge down to the river in the future. That would be an amazing experience in the summer for my kiddos and dog', 'Highly recommended for fun and family day. It’s totally shady trail and easy', 'Nice, easy and well maintained trail...until you get to the end part which looks overgrown but it’s still nice all the same.', 'I was not disappointed with this trail! Lush green ferns, wooden bridges, beautiful waterfalls and well maintained trails. There is plenty of shade to keep you cool. This is now one of my favorite places to hike!', 'This is such a nice trail and such an easy path to follow.  The best feature is the bridge.  A little disappointed in the end of the trail until my son found a beautiful spot to sit and look over the valley and river below. I’ll be back to this one.', 'Loved this Trail.', 'Beautiful hike, kid friendly & easy for non hikers. picnic areas. Options in the area to lengthen your hike.', 'great family hike.', 'Great trail for family!!!!', 'Great easy hike! Lots of trees, and all flat trail. During the wet times of the year you may find some cool red salamanders! The trail is not a loop, so if that’s what you’re looking for it isn’t this', 'Great for the kids', "simple access. good parking but the trail is partially cut off so you can't make a loop.", 'Really great trail, easy to follow and I can see this being family friendly, a large stretch could easily be used for a stroller if you have small kids. Random, I pulled over 50 ticks of my German Shepherd. And 5 ticks off my Lab. The lab tends to not be interested in bushes or smelling, so he stays center to the trail.  But the Shepherd loves to run through bushes and sniff, so maybe there were a lot in the tall grasses? I’d still come back, but maybe during a different time of year.', 'We enjoyed hiking the West Independence Trail yesterday.  We just wanted to point out that we pulled over thirty ticks off our Vizsla and several off of ourselves.', 'beautiful view', 'Shady +, not much climb -, cool bridges ++', 'It depends what you\'re trying to do here. If you want a work out, this isn\'t the trail for you. Extremely flat but very pretty especially during the rainy season. The trail itself is very well maintained, but the bridge and the "Switchback" area I believe it is called need some major love. Lots of holes in the boards, not the most inviting', 'Pretty hot, flat hike, the switchback wasn’t open.', 'The trail is very accessible, easy to follow, and not super crowded. The Switchback is closed unfortunately which was the cool part, and the trail ends suddenly at a road. Bathrooms at the trail entrance, use at your own discretion!', 'Great shaded trail wide enough for stroller (jogging style). No inclines or declines so it was a nice smooth walk or jog. Lots of spots to stop along the way for a break if needed to. Not sure though how far it goes as we only got about about 1.69mi in and there was a large tree across path blocking our safe route with stroller so we called it quits and headed back unfortunately. Would like to try East side next time and see where that goes. Not a ton of parking so get their fairly early. Bathrooms are right at beginning of trail only (pretty typical of a trail of course). After the trail head back in your car another quarter mile up the road and take a nice dip in the beautiful scenic river which also offers more trails but for more advanced hikers.', 'Easy interesting trail and  very pretty. We took a detour via the jones bar trail down to the river and that part was definitely challenging.', 'The bridge was in accessable when we went (October) but otherwise a gorgeous little trek.', 'very beautiful trail!! cool stuff to see from back in the mining days', 'Knawr kwnar.', "Great trail. Really enjoyable views while walking. Even though it's popular, there was quite a distance of time between seeing people.", "Nice hike, very pretty.We did bump it up and did the East, West, and the Jones Bar Loop for a total of 10 miles. Jones Bar Rd. isn't as pretty or well marked; but a great hill workout, with a beautiful pool and falls at the bottom of the steep, rocky trail.", 'Nice hike', 'Wonderful Trail.  Great for hotter days as it has lots of trees as well as options to go to Jones Bar on the South Yuba trail.  It follows a gold rush era flume so amazing rock work abounds.  As other reviewers have noted some repair is needed on some of the bridges but it is easy to access the salamander viewing area and the wonderful swimming areas.', 'Not my favorite trail. Flat. Boring. The part of the trail that is basically a long bridge, needs serious work. There were cones covering up many holes and a lot of the boards are split all the way down the middle. Very unsafe in my opinion. The creek and river were rushing, nice to see so much water lately, but you can find that all over the place.', 'Nice trail but very crowded in the summer.  Like that there are stairs right down to the water.', "This trail was definitely not wheelchair accessible. There were rocks and trees blocking the path and it was narrow, overgrown, and muddy in many places.It was pretty easy and mostly flat. We didn't enjoy it too much, especially after you pass the wooden bridge the path isn't maintained well and for some odd reason my gf and I both got a spooky feeling the further we went but we finished the hike and we were safe.The first mile or so of the hike is the best and all you really need to enjoy it. The bridge and the walkway leading down to the water is the best part but we don't plan on going back.", "Absolutely love this trail! Can't wait to go back to explore a little more! Great place for photographs .. kid friendly. Absolutely beautiful! One thing I didn't like was all the poison oak EVERYWHERE!", "so awesome. take the West trial after .6 miles there is a bench or table every .10 of a mile. about 1 mile is a picnic table. Great for old or young with strollers all flat. bathrooms only at the beginning of the trail  and if you have a stroller or handicap person drop off at the first time parking area past that point it's kinda dangerous to walk across the twisting road.", 'We took the Independence Trail West route and even though it was muddy from all the rain,  it was just beautiful.  It was full of Moss covered rocks and trees and ferns filled the trailhead. It reminded me of a mini Pacific Northwest. The bridges were fun to walk across and photograph. We went early in the morning and had the place to ourselves for a gorgeous, peaceful walk.', "Beautiful hike today! Very dog friendly and the sounds,smells, and foliage were abundant. I can't wait to take my kids and hubby back here. Definitely worth the trip", "Pretty easy trail but because  of recent weather, there's some muddy spots and downed trees. I was still able to push a stroller from the trailhead to jones bar rd. Had to get a little creative over a couple downed trees. The switchback is still closed pending repairs. Otherwise, a wonderful trail. Useable bathrooms located at trailhead. The trailhead for both west and east starts at the same spot. Clearly marked off of 49 parking available at the actual trailhead. First mile or so is wheelchair accessible. Have fun!", "Beautiful easy trail and completely flat for the most part. 3/4/17 we were just out for a drive on 49 and seen the sign. I'm so glad we stopped. Sun was shining and it even hailed a little. The best part of the hike was that the entire trail is wheelchair accessible! But more of a leisurely stroll than a challenging hike. East independence trail was closed due to unsafe condition. We took west and there was a sign saying unsafe structure. A few cones and broken broads from recent weather damage. Creeped me out a lil but safe none the less.", 'Really cool trail.. antique bathrooms ... lol. Great for kids. Some parts are stroller friendly, some not so much. The views were pretty good. The sounds from the river i could listen to for hours!!! Looking forward to going back when the trail is cleaned up a bit. There was a huge tree blocking it so there was no getting through.', 'This is a good beginner trail. It is dog friendly and all trails are marked. Very flat but easy to find off hwy 49', 'Beautiful shaded easy hike', "Like walking through fern gully - perfect November hike - waters rushing and everything is green and full of life.  Totally easy to get to and parking is plentiful.  The trail is well maintained!  There are a few places where cones are set on the mountainside walkway, but nothing in real disrepair - the waterfall outlook is closed right now for new construction but that didn't stop us from visiting it off the beaten path - all in all it's a flat, easy and enjoyable way to get out of the city! Heads up though - this time of year wear hiking boots, tennis shoes will get soggy!", 'Easy but needs repair, see photo.', "Great for kids! Enchanting and really nice trail for any age. My grandson called it being in a dream... He's age 6, nice to view the world through little ones eyes.", "Really gentle trail that's got nice bridges and rocks. Great trail to hike with small kids.", 'Easy, neat little trail. Way easy for kids. Bummer the ramp to the creek was closed.', 'Love the views!! Trail was very picturesque and heading down to the river was definitely worth it.', 'Nice trail and easy for everyone as we saw a family with a twin stroller walking.  We went in the afternoon and it was almost all shade.', 'I loved this trail. It is easy and very well maintained, and the bridges make it fun.', "I've done this a few times, always beautiful, any season. When you're done, go the extra mile and cool off in the South Yuba River State Park!!!", 'Loved this hike with my family!', 'Great views and bridges', "If you are going southbound there are no signs for independence trail. (If there is I must've missed it). But it should be on your right and you see a staircase and some small parking spaces. It's right before the entrance for the South Yuba river so if you drove passed the river you've gone too far.As for the trail, it is fairly easy and the first half of the trail is 10x better than the second half. Just stay at the flume and go back because the second half of the trail is nothing special. It's so dry with the drought, all you see are dry trees and shrubs. Nothing special. I got to the end and it was just an empty dirt road. Not really worth driving 1.5 hours from Sacramento. The water levels are really low so that was unfortunate.", 'I pushed my BOB stroller with my six month old, we also had a 1 year old, 4 year old, 6 year old! The babies had fun splashing in the water and the older boys loved jumping off the rocks and finding the gorgeous Newts! Greatly recommended! Very easy! Very family friendly!', 'Gps takes you to a one lane dirt road with no where to park, 4x4 recommended with high clearance if you try it. Alternatively if you look at others recorded treks you will see they start off of the 45. That is accessible and  well labeled. Highly recommend you start there.', "Love this trail. Have hiked it for many years. It's beautiful and in a great location. Escape the day to day and take a break.", 'The trail is well maintained and the old foot bridges are neat. There are a few decent views. I went out on a Sunday and there was not a lot of traffic, which was nice. The trail is a simple walking trail. Nothing difficult.  As George stated, it is rather dry. It may be nicer when its colder and rained a few times.\n\nI drove from Sacramento. For me, there are better hikes out there. I would not drive out there again and redo this particular hike. It may be a good hike for a local trying to get basic daily exercise, but not for someone traveling over an hour.', 'Very dry. The waterfall had no water in it at all. Bad drought year. The walking flume was fascinating.', 'Good beach and great place to take a family.  Cool in the shade.', "have done this trail too many times to count, with people of all ages and skill levels. just to the creek where the flumes end with ramps is a great destination spot about mile in (I believe this is 2out of the 7miles counting out and back ). if you do the whole loop down to the river it's  a nice workout climbing back up, love it! (i don't think it's included at all in the 7mile count)on opposite side of hwy 49 you can do 5 miles out and back(this seems to be the other total to make 7).", "A very pretty trail. There was some poison oak and a few snakes. We went to the left from the parking area and got to see some really pretty views of the forest and the river. It's really flat almost the entire way, so it's a pretty easy trail. You can't actually get to the river this way, though. We didn't get a chance to go down the trail that goes on the other side of the road, so you might be able to get to the river that way. There is a bathroom at the beginning of the trail, but no where else that we saw.", "Gorgeous, high up on the east side of the trail.  A little dangerous on the ledges the further in we got, but one of the prettiest river hikes I've done this close to civilization.", 'Great trail.  Well maintained and easy for both people and doggies.  Going West you do have access to some water features but yesterday, due to the drought, everything was all dried up.  Such a shame since it looked like it would have been a beautiful waterfall and great place for the dog to get wet.  I save my 5 star ratings for those hikes with National Park style views and experiences.  This is a great trail but nothing too out of the ordinary for this area besides the flumes.  Enjoy.', 'This trail is marked closed right now, possibly for maintenance? Checked it on our  way to buttermilk bend trail nearby. If you go and its still closed Id recommend buttermilk bend as a backup!', "Great for families! We took our 6 year old down the West trail today. There were beautiful lookouts of the waterfalls, and easy accessibility to the ponds below them. Looked for salamanders, but didn't see any. Past the waterfall, there isn't too much to see. We heard the trail that the West trail connects to can get quite steep on the way back up, so we went ahead and turned around so our 6 year old wouldn't struggle too much. We will come back another day to complete the East side!", 'It was a great trail. The views were impressive and it was friendly for the whole family including dogs. ', "A great trail with lots of wide, flat areas. The wooden structures are super nice and make it easy for handicap accessibility for quite a ways. The part of the trail that leads down to the water is steep and rocky, but not difficult. The short trail back up, though, is quite steep. (Keep in mind this was one of my first hikes around here, so after doing the hikes we've been doing since then, I might have a different view of it now.)", 'Super family friendly for all ages. Most beautiful part of the water is just at the top of the rocks, at the top of the waterfall. Have climb for that hidden view. Not really worth it past the waterfall and bridge though.', 'cool n fun', "I've been on this trail several times. It's mostly a family friendly stroll with historical and botanical info as a bonus. Not far from the trailhead to the west is a nice map/illustration which shows historical sites and distances along the way. I like doing the loop this way by continuing all the way to Jones Bar Rd and back up the steep half-mile climb back up to trailhead. The flume system is cool to see along the way.\n\nOn the eastern side, in the spring, I've seen salamanders mating in the creeks that cross the trail.\n\nAll in all it's pleasant day out for all skill levels. ", "They forgot to mention 'super scary' and 'death defying' views on the description.  We took the East side and that was too high, headed back and walked some of the west side of the trail and that was a bit less shocking.  We had our two kids age 6 and 4 with us and they wanted to go look at the Yuba River but we did not make it that far.  Maybe next time.", 'An easy trail, good for a stroll with the family. ', 'As trails go this one is easy. It may be the only wheelchair access trail in the US. On a nearly flat grade it follows an old miners flume used as a water supply for hydraulic mining during Californias gold rush. For a mile and a half westerly from the trailhead (about 5.5 miles north of Nevada City on State Highway 49) the trail crosses creeks and canyons on timber bridges and trestles. A lot of carpentry work went into restoring these old timber flumes. The crossing of Rush Creek canyon is particularly impressive with its long curving timber trestle that at one point branches onto a series of switchbacks down to the edge of Rush Creek where, at this time of year, there is a fine display of white waterfalls spilling into green pools. About half way to the falls a sheltered platform with benches affords a view looking into and across the South Fork of the Yuba River.\nOn this particular day a fourth grade class from a Grass Valley charter school had scheduled a field trip. Out of sight ahead of us they moved along the trail like a flock of sparrows, inquisitive but well behaved, laughing and giggling all the way. We continued past the point where the trail branches, because the children were down below standing in groups waiting for a turn see the green pools and maybe throw a rock in the churning water (at least the boys).\nJust around the bend we found two picnic tables and an outhouse. While we ate our lunch, the fourth graders, all 24 of them, accompanied by their teachers paid a visit to the outhouse. It seems like kids like to visit strange bathroom in restaurants and other places. It comes from their curiosity.\nIn the month of May some wild flowers were blooming, notably iris, globe lilies lupine and Indian paint. Some of the plants are labeled with neatly typed white tags, no doubt prepared by a botanist, because the Latin name is also printed though often unpronounceable. Even some trees are tagged. We were happy to learn that the ponderosa pines were indeed ponderosa and not Jeffrey. If I recall correctly the pitch of Jeffrey pines have that peculiar vanilla odor and their cones are larger than the ponderosa. The labeling is a nice educational touch and a refresher for those of us with aging memories. \nThe westerly piece of the Independence Trail can be turned into a 4.3 mile loop (not suitable for wheelchairs) by continuing on to Jones Bar Road. The shorter option is to retrace your steps about 1.1 miles back to the trailhead.\nIf you want to go the other direction you can walk but you cant drivea wheel chair. An easterly segment of the Independence Trail goes from the trailhead for 2.5 mile. However, the trail is blocked by an uprooted tree and large boulders, so wheel chairs cant make it past this point which is not far from the trailhead, although hikers can easily make it around the blockage.\nA round trip to the falls at a leisurely pace takes a couple of hours. Pushing a wheelchair may take longer.\n', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
El Moro Canyon Short Loop Trail - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['kid friendly', 'birding', 'hiking', 'horseback riding', 'mountain biking', 'nature trips', 'trail running', 'walking', 'beach', 'forest', 'river', 'views', 'wild flowers', 'wildlife', 'no dogs']
hike_description: El Moro Canyon Short Loop Trail is a 2.9 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Laguna Beach, California that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until November. Horses are also able to use this trail.

user_texts: ['Nice walk, though the scenery is a tad monotonous. At the trail junctions, there are helpful little signs to help you get oriented.', 'Loved this trail. All trail mapping is fantastic. So many times I could got lost.', 'Pretty busy. If you start on the north side the incline is very intense and long: my kids were not pleased (4/6) and had to be carried. Trail shoots up then drops down to a flat valley with lots of blooming poison oak right along the trail. State park should remove or control it (it’s everywhere).', 'Nice family hike.The most difficult part is crossing through Poles trail, which is a steep incline of just under half a mile.  I would definitely recommend doing the trail counterclockwise, which would mean taking the incline uphill, but will give you a beautiful ocean view the rest of the way.  Well worth the climb.', 'I\'m not sure who decides the difficulty level for these trails, but I felt like this was on the higher side of "moderate".We parked in at Visitor\'s Center.  You have to pay for parking - $5/hour or $15/day, but they don\'t let you pay hourly on the weekends.Since it\'s a loop, you can do this trail two ways.  We headed South from the Visitor Center to the El Moro Canyon Trail, followed that up the canyon to where it meets Poles and Jeep Trails.  This part of the hike was relatively easy, with a slight incline.  The Poles Trail is short but STEEP... most people were coming down.  Be sure to have a good tread on your footwear if you decided to hike down. At the top of Poles you make a left and head back down to the Visitor Center parking.  The view of the ocean is really nice on the way down, which makes the trek up Poles worth it.', 'Nice hike on a well maintained trail. As expected, no shade on the hike so bring plenty of water. If you go to the right on the trail you stay almost flat for about 1.5 miles til you reach the very steep incline to get to the ridge. If you go to the left the incline is gradual but then you don’t get the view of the water while hiking.', "My 9 year old son and I did this hike. I'm glad we brought our hiking sticks. Some parts were a little steep him, but he did it! We enjoyed it & he would like to do it again with his cub scout pack. The view was great!", 'Nice hike. Strenuous uphill climbs in the beginnings, but nice views of the ocean once you reach a hilltop. Bring shade and plenty of H2O.', 'beautiful view.', 'This was my first time hiking in a while. I found it a little challenging once we reached the steep incline. Had some nice views and the weather was great! Would recommend.', 'Starts off a nice walk then gets really steep. Overall a nice short hike. $15 to park. Same Parking for the hike and beach access.', "Fun trail for family hike. Poles Trail section a  little steep for the little people but hey it's all good.", '', 'Nice wide smooth dirt trails, with some decent hills. $15 all day or $5/hr parking. Multiple trail options.', 'Really great hike! Beautiful view of the ocean at some points. There are a lot of options to make the trail longer or more difficult.', 'This trail was beautiful, with great views of the ocean, and safe paths to follow, with plenty of guide posts for the beginning hikers and all others. I would definitely come here again!', 'hello everybody the hike was great ! View at sunset time was amazing. Be ready to go up seriously the first mile. after that, getting to the view of the mountains on the other side was relaxing and free of car noise :) what a pleasure ! I recommand the hike followed by a beach time to cool off.the only issue about that hike is the 15 dollars daily parking price but I definitively would do again', "Great trail for novice hikers. We were lucky to have an amazing sunny and 75 degree day on Thanksgiving when we hiked this trail. Great ocean views and plenty of trails to choose from as you traverse into the canyon. Day parking is $15 and good for all state parks. Head across the street to the Crystal Cove bluffs (parking covered with your day pass) and walk up and down the beach after your hike. I'll be back for the longer trails soon.", 'Very dry, not much too see until you reach an ocean view. Nevertheless a good hike, not crowded and right smack next to the ocean.', 'Great trail for a first timer hiker.', 'A rather boring trail head with not much vegetation except from random vines with melons growing, but a great and challenging ascend that the kids conquered (ages 6-11).The views of the ocean and ability to easily walk over to the small beach was well worth it. The kids loved running in the water at sunset and cannot wait to camp there next time.', "Nice ocean view from the top.  Otherwise a very boring, dusty trail.  Most of the vegetation is weed and only wildlife is a few birds in the lower part.  Lots of spider webs, if you want to count that as wildlife.  $15 to park your car is outrageous given how awful this hike is.  There are lots of options to extend your hike, but I honestly can't see why you'd want to.  At least you can head over to the beach afterwards to rinse the dust off your legs.  Better yet, skip this hike and walk the beach instead!", "Well-maintained and easy, fun hike. Worth doing for the views and I would even say that it's definitely worth the $15 parking fee. The loop is awesome because it drops you off at the beach, which is really rad.", 'Five stars for the workout getting to the top of the hill and five stars for the view once you get there.  The trail was not crowded at all.  Well-maintained.  Still a beginner at this and so the trek to the top was a little difficult with a backpack full of camera equipment, but once you get there, the views were amazing!', "There were a bunch of different trails to loop around and the maps were very helpful. The hike itself was fairly easy and it wasn't too crowded. however I went just before 8AM. It got busy by about 10. Parking is $15 for the whole day or $5/hr. I'd recommend the day pass. I payed for 2 hours, but I could've stayed for much longer.  The view of the ocean and the surrounding hills and valleys was very pretty. Overall it was super fun and definitely worth checking out.", '', 'beautiful view of the ocean. we went in august though so all the brush was dead, it was crazy hot, and there was no shade. the trail was pretty dusty but alright. we ended up getting lost (and probably taking the long loop) so the hike ended up taking around 3-4 hrs. still a fun hike though!', 'Easy hiking trail near Laguna Beach. Mostly desert scrub brush but has some nice views of the surrounding hills and ocean. At the end of the loop  you can hike to the RV park for a nice view of the Pacific ocean  and adjacent beach.', 'Nice views! Watch out for rattle snakes!', "Pretty view of the Ocean. This was one of my first hikes so its good for beginners too. Moderate difficulty with a few stretches of incline. Most of the trail path is wide and open so the bikers passing by aren't a problem. ", 'The hike was awesome. However, parking cost $15 and there were quite a lot of bikers on the trail. ', "I've only been hiking this area lately.  Are there any good singletrack mtn bike trails here?  We love this area for hiking.", 'Beautiful park after your done hiking in the hills you can hit the beach. We saw deer,rabbit,rattlesnakes,and tons of different birds.I want to camp at one of the back country camps there. ', 'There are lots of rabbits haha! and the ocean views are nice. Good little hike to add to my completed list.', "We backpacked here for a night... The place was good for a one day backpacking trip, although, I'm not sure how multiple day trip would do. The BFI is exactly as named. We saw some wildlife along the way as well as some Tarantulas! The port a potties at the second camp ground were gross and smelled terrible. Pee in the brush. It's very peaceful and quiet at night and gets really dark. At night, It definitely made you feel like you were out in the wilderness. We would definitely do this trail again. =]", 'This is a great guide, Jeff. I just tweeted it on my trailsnet Twitter account.\nThanks for sharing your expertise and wonderful photography.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

hike_name:
Chilnualna Falls Trail - California
 | AllTrails
hike_tags: ['backpacking', 'birding', 'hiking', 'horseback riding', 'nature trips', 'walking', 'forest', 'river', 'views', 'waterfall', 'wildlife', 'bugs', 'no dogs']
hike_description: Chilnualna Falls Trail is a 7.9 mile lightly trafficked out and back trail located near Mariposa, California that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until October. Horses are also able to use this trail.
